p.s: As stated in the summary Obama's speech is about the importance of student exchanges.
Now, I will analyse the structure and choice of words the Obama uses in order to encourage his listeners to take part in intercultural exchanges.
As I already menshionedmentioned in the summary Barack Obama is the 44th president of the USA.
He gave his speech in Istanbul before a student's roundtable in 2009.
The given excerpt can be structured in four different parts.
In the first part, he starts off with his main goal to immediately get the interests of the listeners.
He supports that with adverbs like deeply (l. 1) to underline that.
Another indicator is, that he repeats the adjective mutual in the same sentence.
One that's grounded in mutual interest and mutual respect(l. 2-3).
This also underlines, how important these goals are to him.
In the second part he talks about his own experiences made with people who have done something to help others in other countries.
He calls these people passionate, engaged and deeply informed about the world around them.

These three adjectives and adverbs in relation to people who have done something to help others in other countries support his opinion, that these people arare not only very important to their country, but also very special.
In the third part, Obama mensionsmentions the advantages of student exchanges.
Right at the beginning he uses the metaphermetaphor Simple exchanges can break down walls between us (l. 13).
ThesThese walls resemble the cultural barriers that can be forgotten when you visit other countries in ana student exchange.
This would lead to a life that's productive and purposeful....
This alliteration also supports his opinion about the importance of student exchanges.
In the fourth and last part, Obama encourages the listeners to change something to make the wordworld a better place.
He supports that by saying: ... the world will be what you make it (l. 18).
Directly after that, he refers to his methafermetaphor about the walls between us.
He says, that [We] can choose to build new bridges instead of building new walls (l. 18-19).
This leads to the listeners remembering the metaphermetaphor what results in thinking about it.
In the very last sentence, he calls the USA a partner and a supporter and a friend (l. 21-22).
He does this to underline the important role of the USA in this process.
